boat.name: Sea Breeze
boat.full_description:
Letter to the OGA from Stan Lindsey-Wood, 1987

An account of expenditure on keeping an old boat afloat

I wonder if an account of my expenditure on keeping my old boat afloat over the last 40 years will be of interest to other OGA members. I first started sailing in Morecambe Bay from 1925-1939, and during the war worked in an aircraft works at Hamble near Southampton.

From 1947-1975 I sailed Sea Breeze around the Solent and rebuilt her twice during that time. From 1975 I have been enjoying the Falmouth area for sailing. My accounts for Sea Breeze cover 40 years.

She was owned by a Hamble yacht skipper from 1920-1962, when I bought her from him for the value of the lead keel, which we estimated to be £35. I had a new hollow spruce mast made in 1963, for £50, and fitted an ancient Coventry Victor petrol engine, 50 years old, and a gift. A new propeller was obtained for £6. In 1966 when I obtained my Post War Credits I purchased a new suit of terylene sails for £135 from Williams, at Hamble, and a good second-hand pram dinghy for £5 in 1960.

In 1972 I underwent heart surgery at Southampton, which meant a change to electric starting for the engine, a new Dynastart was obtained for £54. In 1975 I left Hampshire for Cornwall, Sea Breeze was transported from Hamble to Mylor for £95. She was lifted from the transporter into Mylor Creek for £10.74, we bought the mooring with Sea Breeze, and she was collected from Mylor, and laid in Percuil River for us for £35.

Yearly expenditure: 1975-80 approx. £87, 1980 £74.02, 1981 £150.49, 1982  £82.57, 1983 £129.00, 1984 £124.00, 1985 £76.88, 1986 £210.1,7 1987 £98.00. This does not include food and petrol etc.

I wonder if anyone gets cheaper sailing than this.
boat.short_description: Sea Breeze won 2nd Prize in the first Gaffers Race, Solent, 27 July 1959. The widow of her owner since 1947 sold her on his death, she was taken to Scotland. Her tiller is believed to be at the Maritime Museum, Falmouth.
